data.title: Switzerland
data.text:
*** Canton of Appenzell - 1800's ***

Switzerland-Appenzell, Kreuzer, 1813

CANTON APPENZELL

Rampant bear left, V | R across fields in inner circle surrounded by border of dots, laurel wreath below

1 / KREUZER / 1813 

Denomination within laurels

Plain edge

17mm, 0.94g, Billon Silver

Mintage: 86,000

HMZ 56; KM 10

Ex Swiss dealer, November 2001

Switzerland-Appenzell, 1/2 Batzen, 1809

CANTON APPENZELL

Rampant bear left, V | R across fields in inner circle surrounded by laurel wreath, leaf 1809 leaf below

IEDEM DAS SEINIGE

Legend above two branches flanking 1/2 / BATZEN / 5

Plain edge

21mm x 22mm, 1.96g, Billon Silver

Mintage: 60,000

KM 5

Ex Numismatik Lanz, eBay, August 2008

Switzerland-Appenzell, Batzen, 1816

CANTON APPENZELL

Rampant bear left on shield between laurels, V | R across fields, 1816  in exergue

Legend above wreath enclosing 1 / BATZEN / --- / 10, design below

Plain edge

24mm, 2.70g, Billon Silver

Mintage: 203,000

HMZ 54; KM 6

Ex Swiss dealer, November 2001

*** Canton of Appenzell - Non-Circulating Coinage, Tokens & Medals ***

Switzerland-Appenzell, 50 Francs (Shooting Taler), 1986

 EIDGENÖSSISCHES FELDSCHIESSEN APPENZELL  1986

Rampant bear left with ring of stars

EINLÖSBAR AM SCHÜTZENFEST BIS 25. MAI 1986

Pile of arms, flag and palm in foreground, soldier in midground, mountains in background

Incuse edge lettering: GUT FUER 50 Fr. AM SCHUETZENFEST *

37mm, 25.0000g, .900 fine silver, .7235 ASW

Mintage: 3,700 (Proof only) at the Swiss Federal Mint in Bern

KM S26

1977

Festival Token

Switzerland-Bern, 5 Rappen, 1826

* CANTON BERN 1826  5 RAP

Bern arms within dotted circle

* DIE CONCORDIER  CANTONE DER SCHWEIZ

Cross with decorated arms and C in center within laurel circle, flourishes in angles, all within beaded inner circle

Plain edge

23mm x 24mm, 1.72g, Billon Silver

Mintage: Unknown

KM 192

Ex Swiss dealer, February 2001

Notes: Condensed lettering denomination type. The curious thing about this one is the date. As often is the case with this series, this example was overstruck on another coin. The host coin is still peeking through in spots and one such area is a faint C between the 2 and 6 of the date, causing the 6 to look exactly like a 5. There were no 5 rappen pieces struck in Bern in 1925.

Note: When the Monk (who would later become Saint) Gallus came to the woods in what would become St. Gallen, a bear came to help him build his hut. That is how the bear made it into the arms of the canton of St. Gallen.
